title: Collibra
segmentation: Hi so Collibra we put your business into context.
There's no semantics an hour tag.
I need a so who are we?
What are we?
We needed by service company, more semantic enterprise and semantic web.

We facilitate large organizations to easier integrate their business by enabling the business people to really capture their business definitions in the natural language way and using these to drive their technical IT systems.
So we found it in the last year at the spin off from the startup University in Brussels.
We build, sold and installed our product suite.
We solve real market needs which I will talk about.
We fill a large gap and big vendors offering so Oracle partner we talked to tipco SFP Microsoft which we can leverage.
In a partner focused market, go to market strategy.
So who are we are far founders all coming from Star lap stain and I mean stop their PhD to work on collabra.
Peter finishes PhD and is now assistant professor and Amsterdam and ID to master teachers and an MBA before starting Collibra.
So we're all pretty young guys but we have a seasonal board of directors with some executive from IBM, him and so on.
And we raised already an 88150 K seed round involved.
So what do we solve?
So every large complex organization has a lot of different data sources.
A lot of different systems, and all these business concepts have their each each have their different meaning in their different context and context.
Really, as the key organizations are really good at managing their data, there are not good at managing the context in which that data lives.
Let's take an example from the Telecom one of our our opportunities, let's say subscription.
What is the script strips?
And it's always the same thing with telecom operators.
Have fixed line subscriptions.
They have mobile subscriptions and they have Internet subscriptions.

All different contexts which need to be translated in all different IT systems and as a whole interpretation gap and so they are able to manage these business definitions in their respective business context which leads to ambiguity and what we call the business demand side of it, which is really rare.
Opportunity likes, lies like like Mark talked about which leads to proliferation and ICT supply.

A site which we call the IT bunker, and it's indeed very difficult to get in, which leads to misinterpretation, unreliable by reporting data duplication and lack of business, IT alignment, and this again leads to hidden risks, costs an unnecessary debate.
So how do we solve it?
We enable organizations on the business level and that's really key.
It's very, very simple and effect based approach.
Almost natural language.
We have lawyers doing that to manage their business vocabulary, facts and rules in a very easy way and have these drive the traditional technical IT process is.
So we bring technical and business stakeholders together to cover in the business critical information which results in better implemented and integrated ICT systems.
And is a bit of a graphical representation so and they need to see the ID bunker with all the different projects.
And on top you have the demand side which is the business and there lies a huge gap in huge opportunity and you see big organizations struggling.
They try to define this business concept using words.

Then you move to Excel 'cause they need more structure and then you move to wikis because it's really a social process which we need to support and then they elect the structure and so this is where we come in, where we have a product which goes all the way from the top from the business level.
Onto the operational level through our engine.
So what's the opportunity?
The demand side like I talked about as rare opportunity lies because the big vendors really.
They see everything bottom up from a technical perspective and they don't have the answers.

It's an it's an innovative solution, but in well defined IT categories, which means we can reduce the sales cycle, which means we can leverage existing partner networks, system integrators and big vendors to go to the market in an efficient way.
We are positioned to become market leader.
It's a bit ambitious, but we are given the feedback we are getting from industry analysts, baby state technology, forecast reports and so on.
So what market are we targeting targeting?
Mostly government is a huge opportunity.
Banking risk management, insurance, telecom.
Also we have computed or addressable market to be about 450 million 2015 and there's a clear exit strategy because we have these partnerships with these big vendors.
We feel the need, which definitely they will need to address in the future.
But our sales model, currently mostly what I call direct indirect.
So we do direct sales, but we bring partners, system integrators on board as soon as possible because I mean we not credible to do these big projects.
We have partnership with or dinner, Capgemini, Unisys, Deloitte and so on.
So the the.
There's a higher customer acquisition costs, which we want to reduce as much as possible by mean what we call lean and mean.
So we focus on market marketing, lead, lead generation, lead distribution and coaching to its partners and customers.
And by leveraging these large vendors, existing ecosystems, we're building integration with SFP with Microsoft, we have integration with Oracle.
We have integration with.
So the business model very traditional because I mean you have to work together with these integrators with this big vendors.
So we have to kind of model towards their business model.
So perpetual license revenue with recurring.
Minimal service revenue.
We're focused on software licenses, average deal size goes from 5075 K to 1,000,000 for bigger implementations, and I mean the traditional sales.
Cycle time So what have we done?
We've raised 850,000 in August.
We've expanded the team broader, broader season marketing and sales executive on board.
Coming from Microsoft, an Mercury, we built version one of the product sold to customers.
We build a quite a nice pipeline of global customers and partners.
For example, have the largest telco which we're doing together with Oracle.
TIBCO called this.
Can you help us?
We need we need you to.
We have Phillips USUS Department of Defense, Swift, KLM, the ends.
Nokia and a lot of partners to or dinner is is doing and it's big into creating in the Netherlands.
They are building market offering which they called government report.
Go through its healthcare taxes and they seek collibra as in the strategic element and that same thing for system nations recently.
So yeah, a little bit of pressure.
Perfect, so we're raising a new around to have the current investors on.
And we're looking for one more thank you.
